tests.report: - The website can be more accessible, but is rather good!
tests.report_a11y:
- Links do not have a discernible name ( 1.00 rating )
- `[aria-*]` attributes match their roles ( 5.00 rating )
- `[aria-hidden="true"]` is not present on the document `<body>` ( 5.00 rating )
- `[role]`s have all required `[aria-*]` attributes ( 5.00 rating )
- `[aria-*]` attributes have valid values ( 5.00 rating )
- `[aria-*]` attributes are valid and not misspelled ( 5.00 rating )
- Buttons have an accessible name ( 5.00 rating )
- Image elements have `[alt]` attributes ( 5.00 rating )
- `[user-scalable="no"]` is not used in the `<meta name="viewport">` element and the `[maximum-scale]` attribute is not less than 5. ( 5.00 rating )
- ARIA attributes are used as specified for the element's role ( 5.00 rating )
- `[aria-hidden="true"]` elements do not contain focusable descendents ( 5.00 rating )
- Elements use only permitted ARIA attributes ( 5.00 rating )
- `[role]` values are valid ( 5.00 rating )
- Background and foreground colors have a sufficient contrast ratio ( 5.00 rating )
- Document has a `<title>` element ( 5.00 rating )
- `<html>` element has a `[lang]` attribute ( 5.00 rating )
- `<html>` element has a valid value for its `[lang]` attribute ( 5.00 rating )
- Touch targets have sufficient size and spacing. ( 5.00 rating )
- Elements with visible text labels do not have matching accessible names. ( 1.00 rating )
- Heading elements appear in a sequentially-descending order ( 5.00 rating )
- Uses ARIA roles only on compatible elements ( 5.00 rating )
- Deprecated ARIA roles were not used ( 5.00 rating )
- Image elements do not have `[alt]` attributes that are redundant text. ( 5.00 rating )
- Document has a main landmark. ( 5.00 rating )

aria-allowed-attr.title: `[aria-*]` attributes match their roles
aria-allowed-attr.description: Each ARIA `role` supports a specific subset of `aria-*` attributes. Mismatching these invalidates the `aria-*` attributes. [Learn how to match ARIA attributes to their roles](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-allowed-attr).

aria-allowed-role.title: Uses ARIA roles only on compatible elements
aria-allowed-role.description: Many HTML elements can only be assigned certain ARIA roles. Using ARIA roles where they are not allowed can interfere with the accessibility of the web page. [Learn more about ARIA roles](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-allowed-role).

aria-conditional-attr.title: ARIA attributes are used as specified for the element's role
aria-conditional-attr.description: Some ARIA attributes are only allowed on an element under certain conditions. [Learn more about conditional ARIA attributes](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-conditional-attr).

aria-deprecated-role.title: Deprecated ARIA roles were not used
aria-deprecated-role.description: Deprecated ARIA roles may not be processed correctly by assistive technology. [Learn more about deprecated ARIA roles](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-deprecated-role).

aria-hidden-body.title: `[aria-hidden="true"]` is not present on the document `<body>`
aria-hidden-body.description: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, work inconsistently when `aria-hidden="true"` is set on the document `<body>`. [Learn how `aria-hidden` affects the document body](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-hidden-body).

aria-hidden-focus.title: `[aria-hidden="true"]` elements do not contain focusable descendents
aria-hidden-focus.description: Focusable descendents within an `[aria-hidden="true"]` element prevent those interactive elements from being available to users of assistive technologies like screen readers. [Learn how `aria-hidden` affects focusable elements](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-hidden-focus).

aria-prohibited-attr.title: Elements use only permitted ARIA attributes
aria-prohibited-attr.description: Using ARIA attributes in roles where they are prohibited can mean that important information is not communicated to users of assistive technologies. [Learn more about prohibited ARIA roles](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-prohibited-attr).

aria-required-attr.title: `[role]`s have all required `[aria-*]` attributes
aria-required-attr.description: Some ARIA roles have required attributes that describe the state of the element to screen readers. [Learn more about roles and required attributes](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-required-attr).

aria-roles.title: `[role]` values are valid
aria-roles.description: ARIA roles must have valid values in order to perform their intended accessibility functions. [Learn more about valid ARIA roles](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-roles).

aria-valid-attr-value.title: `[aria-*]` attributes have valid values
aria-valid-attr-value.description: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid values. [Learn more about valid values for ARIA attributes](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-valid-attr-value).

aria-valid-attr.title: `[aria-*]` attributes are valid and not misspelled
aria-valid-attr.description: Assistive technologies, like screen readers, can't interpret ARIA attributes with invalid names. [Learn more about valid ARIA attributes](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/aria-valid-attr).

button-name.title: Buttons have an accessible name
button-name.description: When a button doesn't have an accessible name, screen readers announce it as "button", making it unusable for users who rely on screen readers. [Learn how to make buttons more accessible](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/button-name).

color-contrast.title: Background and foreground colors have a sufficient contrast ratio
color-contrast.description: Low-contrast text is difficult or impossible for many users to read. [Learn how to provide sufficient color contrast](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/color-contrast).

document-title.title: Document has a `<title>` element
document-title.description: The title gives screen reader users an overview of the page, and search engine users rely on it heavily to determine if a page is relevant to their search. [Learn more about document titles](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/document-title).

heading-order.title: Heading elements appear in a sequentially-descending order
heading-order.description: Properly ordered headings that do not skip levels convey the semantic structure of the page, making it easier to navigate and understand when using assistive technologies. [Learn more about heading order](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/heading-order).

html-has-lang.title: `<html>` element has a `[lang]` attribute
html-has-lang.description: If a page doesn't specify a `lang` attribute, a screen reader assumes that the page is in the default language that the user chose when setting up the screen reader. If the page isn't actually in the default language, then the screen reader might not announce the page's text correctly. [Learn more about the `lang` attribute](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/html-has-lang).

html-lang-valid.title: `<html>` element has a valid value for its `[lang]` attribute
html-lang-valid.description: Specifying a valid [BCP 47 language](https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags#question) helps screen readers announce text properly. [Learn how to use the `lang` attribute](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/html-lang-valid).

image-alt.title: Image elements have `[alt]` attributes
image-alt.description: Informative elements should aim for short, descriptive alternate text. Decorative elements can be ignored with an empty alt attribute. [Learn more about the `alt` attribute](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/image-alt).

image-redundant-alt.title: Image elements do not have `[alt]` attributes that are redundant text.
image-redundant-alt.description: Informative elements should aim for short, descriptive alternative text. Alternative text that is exactly the same as the text adjacent to the link or image is potentially confusing for screen reader users, because the text will be read twice. [Learn more about the `alt` attribute](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/image-redundant-alt).

label-content-name-mismatch.title: Elements with visible text labels do not have matching accessible names.
label-content-name-mismatch.description: Visible text labels that do not match the accessible name can result in a confusing experience for screen reader users. [Learn more about accessible names](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/label-content-name-mismatch).

landmark-one-main.title: Document has a main landmark.
landmark-one-main.description: One main landmark helps screen reader users navigate a web page. [Learn more about landmarks](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/landmark-one-main).

node.explanation:
Fix all of the following:
  Document does not have a main landmark

link-name.title: Links do not have a discernible name
link-name.description: Link text (and alternate text for images, when used as links) that is discernible, unique, and focusable improves the navigation experience for screen reader users. [Learn how to make links accessible](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/link-name).

node.explanation:
Fix all of the following:
  Element is in tab order and does not have accessible text

Fix any of the following:
  Element does not have text that is visible to screen readers
  aria-label attribute does not exist or is empty
  aria-labelledby attribute does not exist, references elements that do not exist or references elements that are empty
  Element has no title attribute

meta-viewport.title: `[user-scalable="no"]` is not used in the `<meta name="viewport">` element and the `[maximum-scale]` attribute is not less than 5.
meta-viewport.description: Disabling zooming is problematic for users with low vision who rely on screen magnification to properly see the contents of a web page. [Learn more about the viewport meta tag](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/meta-viewport).

target-size.title: Touch targets have sufficient size and spacing.
target-size.description: Touch targets with sufficient size and spacing help users who may have difficulty targeting small controls to activate the targets. [Learn more about touch targets](https://dequeuniversity.com/rules/axe/4.10/target-size).
